flow.context: Alex Hunter is a Property Management Specialist at Carolina One Vacation Rentals, running their Freshfields Village / Johns Island office covering the Kiawah and Seabrook Island corridor. He directly owns the inspection and turnover readiness process for that area — pre-arrival inspections, vendor coordination, owner communication. Carolina One manages roughly 300-400 luxury coastal vacation rentals across Charleston's barrier islands using Streamline as their PMS and Breezeway for turnover ops and photo capture, and they explicitly promise owners a day-of pre-arrival inspection on every check-in. The company is actively expanding with new office locations and hiring property managers, meaning more volume and more chances for things to slip. No personal connection to Sam — lead with industry and geographic proximity and lean hard on the Breezeway integration angle since that is exactly where RapidEye plugs in.

start_call.label: INITIAL CONTACT
start_call.note: Quick routing check. If Alex picks up, move to opener. If someone else answers, slide into gatekeeper mode. Sound casual and familiar.

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper.say: Could you get me over to Alex? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Don't volunteer last name or company. Sound like you know him. Keep it to one sentence.

branches.label: They ask who's calling or what it's about

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other vacation rental managers in the Charleston area. Would you mind letting Alex know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Just enough to sound legit. Still no pitch. Still no company name unless forced.

branches.label: They push back or want more detail

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand. We help a couple property management companies with their turnover inspection workflows — I sent Alex a note earlier. Would you mind giving him a heads up?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Last attempt. If still blocked, ask for voicemail or best time to reach Alex directly on his cell.

branches.label: Still blocked or take a message

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Alex — I work with a few other vacation rental managers along the Charleston coast on their inspection workflows. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Relaxed. Feet up on the desk energy. You're a peer, not a telemarketer. Pause after the question and let him respond.

branches.label: No or doesn't ring a bell
Skeptical or cold or who is this

heard_name_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your role on the inspection side. What'd you hear?
heard_name_yes.note: Let him talk. Don't correct anything he says. Whatever he shares, bridge into discovery.

branches.label: Shares what he knows or is curious

heard_name_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well, the reason for my call —
heard_name_no.note: Quick self-deprecating laugh. Don't dwell on it. Transition straight into the pain trigger.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again later this week? Maybe Thursday or Friday afternoon?
bad_timing.note: Don't be needy. Give two specific day options. Lock in the callback if you can.

branches.label: Sure, try me at a specific time
Not interested or don't call back

callback_set.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
callback_set.say: Perfect — I'll give you a ring then. Appreciate it, Alex.
callback_set.note: Write down the exact day and time immediately. Set a calendar reminder. This is a warm callback now — treat it that way.

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION REQUEST
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? You can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Disarming honesty. Most people respect the transparency and give you the 30 seconds. Keep your tone easy.

branches.label: No thanks or still not interested

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION DENIED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: You're splitting the no to understand the real reason. This often re-engages people who were just reflexively brushing you off.

branches.label: Wait — what do you guys do?

split_rejection.label: SPLIT THE REJECTION
split_rejection.say: Totally fair. Last thing — is it that inspection quality honestly isn't a pain point for you guys right now, or is it more that you just hate getting cold called? Either way I get it.
split_rejection.note: Final attempt to surface a real objection. If he's truly done, end gracefully. But sometimes this unlocks the real conversation.

branches.label: Not a pain point for us
Hates cold calls or just not right now
Actually it is a pain point

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: I was talking to another property manager who runs a setup that's pretty close to yours — luxury coastal vacation rentals, few hundred homes spread across barrier islands, cleaners using Breezeway to upload photos after every turnover. And his whole thing was, they promise owners a pre-arrival inspection on every single check-in day. But with the volume — especially heading into season — nobody on his team actually has time to look through every photo set before the next guest walks in. So stuff slips. A stain on a white sofa. A cracked tile that got missed. Patio furniture staged wrong. And when you're charging four or five grand a week on a beachfront place, that's the kind of thing that ends up in a guest review or an owner calling asking what happened.
pain_trigger.note: STOP TALKING. Pause. Let the silence sit for a full three seconds. Wait for Alex to react before you say another word. The pause is where the magic happens.

branches.label: He relates or agrees — yeah that's real
He asks what you do about it

solution_and_cta.label: SOLUTION AND CTA
solution_and_cta.say: We built something that plugs right into Breezeway and automatically analyzes the turnover photos your cleaners are already uploading — flags damage, missing items, staging issues — before the guest walks in. Zero workflow change on your team's end. Would you be open to taking a look when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
solution_and_cta.note: One sentence on the product. One sentence CTA. Then shut up. Don't oversell. Let him respond.

branches.label: Sure or I'd look at that
Not right now or no budget

warm_response.label: THEY'RE WARM — START DISCOVERY
warm_response.say: Awesome. I don't want to just pitch at you — I'd rather understand what you guys are doing now. What does your inspection workflow actually look like on a turnover day?
warm_response.note: STOP SELLING. You are in discovery mode. Listen more than you talk. Take notes on everything he says — tools, pain points, team structure.

discovery_process.label: DISCOVERY — CURRENT PROCESS
discovery_process.say: Got it. And the photos your cleaners or vendors are taking after turnovers — how does the review side work? Is someone on your team looking at every set before check-in, or is it more of a spot-check when there's time?
discovery_process.note: You're probing for the gap between what they capture and what they actually review. That gap is exactly where RapidEye lives.

discovery_breezeway.label: DISCOVERY — BREEZEWAY DEEP DIVE
discovery_breezeway.say: Oh nice — so you guys are on Breezeway for the turnover checklists and photo capture? That's actually perfect because we plug directly into it. Your cleaners don't change a thing on their end. How happy are you with what Breezeway gives you on the actual photo review side?
discovery_breezeway.note: Breezeway captures photos but doesn't do AI-powered analysis. Probe for the gap between capture and review — that's the wedge.

branches.label: Mostly happy but sees gaps in photo review

discovery_pain_points.label: DISCOVERY — PAIN POINTS
discovery_pain_points.say: Yeah that makes sense. What's been the biggest headache for you personally on the turnover side — is it more the sheer volume of inspections, the consistency of what actually gets caught, or something else entirely?
discovery_pain_points.note: Let him vent. Mentally map whatever he says to how RapidEye solves it. But don't pitch yet — let him feel heard first.

branches.label: Volume — can't keep up with inspections
Quality — things slipping through the cracks
Owner complaints or guest review issues

tie_back_and_book.label: TIE BACK AND BOOK
tie_back_and_book.say: Yeah — that's literally why we built this. I don't want to oversell it on a cold call though. I think if I showed you what it looks like on actual turnover photos — how it flags stuff automatically and what the report looks like for your team — it'd click pretty fast. I've got next Tuesday or Wednesday open. Does either work for a quick twenty minutes?
tie_back_and_book.note: Bridge his specific pain directly to the demo. Pick real days. Be specific on time. Lock it down now.

branches.label: Wants to loop in Win or someone else
Pushes back or not right now

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Perfect — how does two o'clock look? I'll fire over a calendar invite right now so it doesn't get buried. What's the best email — alex.hunter@carolinaone.com?
book_meeting.note: Lock in day AND time. Confirm the email. Send the invite WHILE on the phone if possible. Once it's booked, STOP SELLING.

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_booked.say: Awesome — just sent that over. Really appreciate you taking my call, Alex. Talk to you then.
meeting_booked.note: Done. Do not keep pitching. Do not add one more thing. End clean on a high note. Send the invite immediately after hanging up if you haven't already.

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that inspection quality honestly isn't something on your radar right now, or is it more that you just hate getting cold called?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. It disarms them. Then split the objection into two pieces to understand the real no.

branches.label: Inspections aren't a focus right now
Hates cold calls or bad timing
Opens up about a real pain point

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with close to four hundred properties you'd have to have something solid in place. Just curious — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how Breezeway handles the photo review piece, or is it more that adding anything right now would just be a headache?
objection_have_process.note: RapidEye does NOT replace Breezeway — it sits on top and analyzes photos Breezeway already collects. If he thinks it's a replacement, clarify immediately. If photo review is the gap, that's your opening.

branches.label: Adding anything is a headache right now
Actually photo review is a gap for us

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it — nowadays it's hard enough to keep the tools you already have, let alone bring something new in. Just so I know — is it that budget for this year is completely locked up, or is it more that anything you try to buy puts you through the ringer with approvals up the chain?
objection_no_budget.note: Split budget versus approval process. If it's an approval chain issue, ask who signs off — likely Win Walker or someone at the Carolina One parent level. That becomes your next call.

branches.label: Budget is locked for the year
Actually it's more of a priority question

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally fair. Look — you're probably not buying something today and I respect that. But when budget does open up or you're looking at tools heading into next season, the people who move fast are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to a quick twenty minutes — not to buy anything — just so you know what's out there? Worst case I walk you through what other PM companies along the coast are doing with their turnover photos and you steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive.note: You're selling the value of the meeting itself, not the product. The meeting has standalone value even if he never buys. If he's still cold after this, don't push.

branches.label: Talk to someone else on my team

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. Quick question before I do — what would be most useful to include so it doesn't just sit in your inbox like every other vendor email? Is it more the Breezeway integration piece, or the kind of stuff it actually catches during turnovers?
send_email.note: Asking what to include gives you intel on what matters to him AND makes it way more likely he actually opens it.

branches.label: Tells you what he wants to see
Just send whatever or general info

send_email_confirm.label: CONFIRM EMAIL AND CLOSE
send_email_confirm.say: Got it — I'll put something together and shoot it over to alex.hunter@carolinaone.com. I'll throw a couple time options in there in case you want to hop on a quick call after you look at it. Appreciate your time, Alex.
send_email_confirm.note: Confirm the email address. Send within two hours. Include two or three specific time options in the email body. Follow up 48 hours later if no response.

not_right_person.label: NOT THE RIGHT PERSON
not_right_person.say: Totally hear you. Who on your team would typically own something like this — would that be more of a Win Walker decision, or is there somebody on the ops side who runs the inspection workflow?
not_right_person.note: You know Win Walker is Vacation Rentals Director and Amber Donevant is Revenue and Ops Manager. Dropping Win's name shows you did your homework and usually gets a reaction. If Alex names either one, you have their contact info.

branches.label: Mentions Amber Donevant or another name

referral_ask.label: ASK FOR REFERRAL
referral_ask.say: No worries. If I reach out to the right person it'll land way better than another cold call. Who would you point me to for anything related to turnover quality or inspections? Even a first name helps — I can put something tailored together so it actually gets read.
referral_ask.note: Push for a name. Even a first name or a title is gold. If he gives you Win or Amber, you already have their contact info ready to go.

referral_get_name.label: GET CONTACT DETAILS
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — and what's the best way to reach them, email or phone? I want to make sure what I send doesn't just look like cold outreach.
referral_get_name.note: If Win Walker: win@carolinaone.com and (843) 242-3012. If Amber Donevant: try amber.donevant@carolinaone.com. Confirm whatever Alex gives you.

branches.label: Says just call the main office

referral_bridge.label: NAME DROP PERMISSION
referral_bridge.say: Really appreciate that, Alex. Mind if I mention your name when I reach out? Goes a lot further coming from someone on the team than a random cold call.
referral_bridge.note: Permission to name-drop turns your next call from cold to warm. Even a casual sure whatever is enough to use.

graceful_end.label: END GRACEFULLY
graceful_end.say: Totally understand. If anything changes or you guys start looking at the inspection side heading into season, I'm easy to find. Appreciate your time, Alex.
graceful_end.note: Don't burn the bridge. Send a brief follow-up email with your contact info regardless of how the call went. Add to 30-60-90 day follow-up cadence.
